Vaccines are allocated by the State according to permanent resident population, so vaccination appointments are **only for** **people who work or live in Tuolumne County, regardless of immigration status. **To ensure Tuolumne County is administering vaccines according to State guidelines, **proof of eligibility is now required at the vaccination clinics**. 

### **Where:**
Vaccine is being administered primarily at Closed Points of Dispensing (PODs) **by appointment.** You can find most recent locations compiled by our volunteers, by visiting <https://www.vaccinateca.com/counties/Tuolumne.html>

Individuals who are eligible to be vaccinated are encouraged to contact their personal healthcare provider for vaccine information and to check for availability.
### How to Make an Appointment:
If you are in an eligible Phase and Tier, you can fill out the Tuolumne County COVID-19 Vaccination **Interest Form** at <https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=f7_iN8RLhUCeCq6rg_E6Hg1TRUz5AN9Fh5_US45ucbRUNUpEMk1MQ0Y1QkcwMjY3TE5YS1hHUkZaUi4u>. Public Health staff will follow up with you when vaccine becomes available and an appointment slot opens up.
### County status:
Shipments of Pfizer and Moderna vaccine have been received in Tuolumne County and we continue to receive additional shipments of first and second doses, primarily the Moderna vaccine. Some of the vaccine was redistributed to our neighboring counties as part of the statewide distribution plan, and vaccinations have been administered to individuals according to the State's [phased plan](https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccines/#When-can-I-get-vaccinated). More shipments of vaccine are expected in the coming weeks and months, yet the situation remains fluid. As new details become available regarding COVID-19 vaccines, Tuolumne County Public Health will update the information on the [county website](https://www.tuolumnecounty.ca.gov/1317/COVID-Vaccine).

# [Feb 1] Appointments released for 5 clinics this week for 75+

Appointments available at https://www.yolocounty.org/coronavirus-vaccine.

Yolo County is now vaccinating residents 75+. For the remaining residents who are in Phase 1B Tier 1, please fill out the County's vaccine interest form in [English, Spanish or Russian.](http://bit.ly/VaccineAvailability)

Due to limited weekly doses, the County has decided to prioritize seniors 75 and older who are at greatest risk for serious complications or death from COVID-19. 
Multi-County Entities, such as Sutter Health, UC Davis Health, Dignity Health and Kaiser Permanente, are also administering the COVID-19 vaccine. If residents over 65+ receive health care through one of these entities, the County recommends contacting them first for vaccine options. However, their supplies are also limited so it will take time to offer everyone eligible an appointment. 

For more information about Yolo County’s COVID-19 vaccine and distribution process, visit <https://www.yolocounty.org/coronavirus-vaccine>.

## To make an appointment:
Adults 75+ can make an appointment for vaccine clinics at https://www.yolocounty.org/coronavirus-vaccine

If you are homebound and need an in-home vaccine, call 211 or their toll free number: (855) 866-1783.

Individuals who are 65+ are encouraged to contact their personal healthcare provider for information for vaccine information and to check for availability.

You can also find most recent county-level information compiled by our volunteers by visiting <https://www.vaccinateca.com/counties/Yolo.html>

**To make an appointment: **

- Appointments can be scheduled by visiting Butte County COVID-19 Vaccination Clinic sign-up portal:  [tinyurl.com/COVIDvax75](https://tinyurl.com/COVIDvax75?fbclid=IwAR2DLzaS5hD9brebGeGOvo18eMt3XNuqkqk74bdCl6yowmNM1nl-qB3r-Ns)

Now that COVID vaccine appointment scheduling is available online, As of Feb 1st, Butte County Public Health (BCPH) will stop taking registration for the COVID vaccine e-mail notification. Over the past month, local interest in the COVID-19 vaccine has grown large, which bodes well for turning the pandemic tide in Marin County. Now, health officials are taking a coordinated step forward in how best to allocate a still-limited supply of the shots to those most vulnerable to hospitalization or death from COVID-19.
